facts.text: Petition Nos. 145 and 149 to 158 of 1959 filed under Original Jurisdiction as Writ Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition Nos. 145 and 149 to 158 of 1959. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 30, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These eleven petitions raise a companymon point and will be disposed of together.

facts.text: Eleven petitions raise a common point and disposed of together.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These eleven petitions raise a companymon point and will be disposed of together. The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these.

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers in motor spirit in Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The petitioners are dealers in motor spirit in Hyderabad.

facts.text: Hyderabad Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Regulation, No. XXIV of 1358 Fasli passed in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In 1949 the Hyderabad Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Regulation, No. XXIV of 1358 Fasli  hereinafter called the Regulation  was passed and the petitioners were registered as retail dealers of petroleum products under the Regulation.

facts.text: Petitioners registered as retail dealers of petroleum products under the Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the Regulation  was passed and the petitioners were registered as retail dealers of petroleum products under the Regulation. In 1957 the petitioners and others filed writ petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh questioning the validity of the Regulation.

facts.text: In 1957 petitioners and others filed writ petitions in High Court of Andhra Pradesh questioning validity of the Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957 the petitioners and others filed writ petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh questioning the validity of the Regulation. There was also a prayer for stay of the levy and companylection of the tax and the High Court ordered that all further proceedings in the matter of levy, demand and companylection of tax including cancellation of registration certificate and threatened attachment of property and the launching of criminal proceedings in pursuance of the Regulation be stayed.

facts.text: High Court ordered stay of levy, collection of tax, cancellation of registration, attachment, criminal proceedings under Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: There was also a prayer for stay of the levy and companylection of the tax and the High Court ordered that all further proceedings in the matter of levy, demand and companylection of tax including cancellation of registration certificate and threatened attachment of property and the launching of criminal proceedings in pursuance of the Regulation be stayed.

facts.text: Petitioners allege that due to High Court stay, they thought S.3 of Regulation suspended and stopped collecting tax from consumers.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners allege that on this stay being granted by the High Court, they thought that S. 3 of the Regulation was suspended during the period of stay and therefore they stopped companylecting the tax from companysumers.

facts.text: While High Court petitions pending, Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation (Andhra Pradesh Extension and Amendment) Act, No. V of 1958 passed, applying Madras Act VI of 1939 to Andhra Pradesh with modifications, repealing Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: While these petitions were pending in the High Court, the Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation  Andhra Pradesh Extension and Amendment  Act, No. V of 1958  hereinafter called the Act , was passed by which the Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Act, No. VI of 1939 was applied to Andhra Pradesh with some modifications and the Regulation was repealed.

facts.text: Fresh registration certificates issued to petitioners and all other dealers in the State under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This Act, like the Regulation, had provisions for registration of dealers and in companysequence fresh registration certificates were issued to the petitioners as well as to all other dealers in the State.

facts.text: In August 1958, High Court petitions challenging Regulation dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In August 1958 the petitions challenging the validity of the Regulation were dismissed.

facts.text: In September 1958, notices issued to petitioners for failing to submit returns showing sales of motor spirit from March 1957 to March 1958, required to submit within seven days or best judgment assessments.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1958 numberice were issued to the petitioners informing them that they had failed to submit returns showing sales of motor spirit from March 1957 to March 1958 and they were required to submit returns within seven days, failing which best judgment assessments would be made under the relevant provision of the Regulation.

facts.text: Petitioners made representations against notices, main case that they had not collected tax from consumers during period and harsh to demand tax.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners made repre- sentations against this order and their main case was that they had number companylected any tax from companysumers during this period and it would therefore be harsh to demand tax from them in the circumstances.

facts.text: Best judgment assessments made against petitioners, required to pay tax, liberty to pay in installments granted.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon it is said that best judgment- assessments were made against the petitioners and they were required to pay the tax, though liberty to pay in installments was granted to them for this purpose.

facts.text: Petitioners failed to deposit tax even in installments.

anchor.surface_text: As however the petitioners failed to deposit the tax even in installments, the registration certificate of one of the petitioners was cancelled and other petitioners were threatened with cancellation of their registration certificates about October 1959.

facts.text: Registration certificate of one petitioner cancelled, other petitioners threatened with cancellation about October 1959.

anchor.surface_text: As however the petitioners failed to deposit the tax even in installments, the registration certificate of one of the petitioners was cancelled and other petitioners were threatened with cancellation of their registration certificates about October 1959.

facts.text: Present petitions filed soon after October 1959 challenging provisions of Act relating to cancellation of registration certificates.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the present petitions were filed soon after challenging the provisions of the Act relating to cancellation of registration certificates on the ground that such cancellation was number a reasonable restriction on the fundamental rights of the petitioners to carry on business under Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondents opposed petitions, case that provisions are reasonable restrictions under Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The petitions have been opposed by the respondents and their case is that the provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19  1   g  and are therefore perfectly valid and companystitutional.

facts.text: Respondents allege that petitioners' claim of not collecting tax during stay period from consumers is false.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents also say that the allegation of the petitioners that they did number companylect the tax during the period of the stay orders from companysumers is false.

facts.text: Act passed to levy and collect tax on retail sales of motor spirit for general revenues of the State.

anchor.surface_text: In order to decide the companystitutionality of the provisions which have been challenged it is necessary to look into the purpose and object of the Act in which those provisions appear. The Act was passed in order to levy and companylect tax on retail sales of motor spirit in the interest of the general revenues of the State.

facts.text: Petitioners pray for declaration that sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s.4 of Act and r.14 ultra vires violating Art.19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners therefore pray for a declaration that sub-ss.  1  and  6  of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 purported to be framed thereunder are ultra vires as being violative of Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution and for companysequential orders against the respondents, namely, the State of Andhra Pradesh and its officers, from enforcing the said provisions.
Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 purported to be framed thereunder are ultra vires as being violative of Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners therefore pray for a declaration that sub-ss.  1  and  6  of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 purported to be framed thereunder are ultra vires as being violative of Art. 19  1   g

issues.text: Whether s. 4(1) of the Act is constitutional or imposes a restriction violative of Art. 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: The challenge therefore to the constitutionality of s. 4 1  must fail. Then we turn to sub-s.  6 , which provides that any registration under sub-section  1  may be suspended or cancelled by such authority,

issues.text: Whether sub-s. (6) of s. 4 of the Act authorises unreasonable restriction on Art. 19(1)(g) by allowing cancellation of registration which results in total extinction of business

anchor.surface_text: The main attack of the petitioners is on this sub-section. They contend that this sub-section authorises the State to cancel a registration.The effect of such cancellation read with sub-s.  1  is that a person whose registration is cancelled cannot carry

issues.text: Whether the provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(g) and therefore perfectly valid

anchor.surface_text: The petitions have been opposed by the respondents and their case is that the provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19  1   g  and are therefore perfectly valid and constitutional.

arguments.claim: Cancellation of registration certificates under the Act is not a reasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on business under Art. 19(1)(g), and sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s.4 and r.14 are ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the present petitions were filed soon after challenging the provisions of the Act relating to cancellation of registration certificates on the ground that such cancellation was not a reasonable restriction on the fundamental rights of the petitioners to carry on business under Art. 19 (1) (g ) of the Constitution. The petitioners therefore pray for a declaration that sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 purported to be framed thereunder are ultra vires as being violative of Art. 19 (1) (g ) of the Constitution and for consequential orders against the respondents, namely, the State of Andhra Pradesh and its officers, from enforcing the said provisions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: order to levy and companylect tax on retail sales of motor spirit in the interest of the general revenues of the State. Section 2 of the Act is the d

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions are reasonable and necessary for tax collection and enforcement; upheld after applying reasonableness test including precedent.

arguments.claim: The provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(g) and therefore perfectly valid and constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions have been opposed by the respondents and their case is that the provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19 (1) (g ) and are therefore perfectly valid and constitutional.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: order to levy and companylect tax on retail sales of motor spirit in the interest of the general revenues of the State. Section 2 of the Act is the d

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees and elaborates that registration and cancellation are reasonable for revenue collection.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) requires registration which is eminently reasonable to enable the State to identify dealers and collect tax, not a restriction on business.

anchor.surface_text: In order therefore that the State may have a check on the person from whom the tax is due s. 4 (1) provides for registration of dealers who carry on the business in motor spirit. Without such registration it would be impossible for the State to know the persons who are selling motor spirit and from whom the tax is due. The provision therefore under s. 4 (1) for registration of dealers is an eminently reasonable provision in order to carry out the object of the Act, namely, the levy and collection of this tax for purposes of the State. It is really not restriction on carrying on business in motor spirit any one who carries on such business is free to do so and all that he has to do is to ask for registration, which he will get subject to the provisions of sub-s. (4).

arguments.claim: Challenge to constitutionality of s.4(1) must fail.

anchor.surface_text: The challenge therefore to the constitutionality of s. 4 (1) must fail.

arguments.claim: s.4(6) providing for suspension or cancellation of registration is a reasonable coercive method to compel payment of tax due, justified in public interest even if it leads to extinction of business.

anchor.surface_text: Then we turn to sub-s. (6), which provides that any registration under sub-s. (1) may be suspended or cancelled by such authority, for such reasons, and in such manner, as may be prescribed. ... Therefore the provision for cancellation of registration for failure to pay the tax or for fraudulently evading the payment of it is an additional coercive process which is expected to be immediately effective and enables the State to realise its revenues which are necessary for carrying on the administration in the interest of the general public.

arguments.claim: Word 'restriction' under Arts.19(5),(6) includes prohibition; total restraint ok if reasonable, per Narendra Kumar precedent; applies proportionality test considering evil remedied, harm ratio, public benefit, necessity.

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to Narendra Kumar v. The Union of India (1), where it was held that the word restriction in Arts. 19 (5) and 19 (6) of the Constitution includes cases of prohibition also that where a restriction reaches the stage of total restraint of rights special care has to be taken by the Court to see that the test of reasonableness is satisfied by considering the question in the background of the facts and circumstances under which the order was made, taking into account the nature of the evil that was sought to be remedied by such law, the ratio of the harm caused to individual citizens by the proposed remedy, the beneficial effect reasonably expected to result to the general public, and whether the restraint caused by the law was more than was necessary in the interests of the general public.

arguments.claim: Cancellation justified even if extinguishes business, as tax for general revenues necessary for public administration.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests we are of opinion that the cancellation of registration will be justified even though it results in the extinction of business as such cancellation is in respect of a tax meant for the general revenues of the State to carry on the administration in the interest of the general public.

arguments.claim: Rule 14 is valid as within rule-making power under s.26 if s.4 constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 which has been attacked has been made under the power conferred under s. 26 and it is not being disputed that if the main provisions contained in s. 4 are constitutional, the rule is within the ambit of the Act and the rule making power of the State Government.

arguments.claim: Dealer collects tax from consumer via price and must remit to State; failure or evasion is dealer's fault, justifying cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, there is another consideration to which we may advert in the end, though even otherwise the cancellation is justified. Though there is no provision in the Act or the Rules specifically authorising the seller to pass on the tax to the consumer, what actually happens is that the seller includes the tax in the price and thus passes it on to the consumer. Then in his turn the seller pays the tax to the State. In effect by thus passing on the tax to the consumer through the price, the dealer has already collected the tax. Therefore the compulsion of payment which arises because of the provision for cancellation of registration is under the circumstances justified and there is no reason why he should fail to pay it to the State or evade payment thereof fraudulently. The fault for failure to pay the tax or fraudulent evasion in payment thereof lies in the circumstances entirely on the dealer and he cannot be heard to complain that cancellation of registration in such a case is a disproportionate restriction on the right to carry on business which cannot be justified in the interests of the general public.

holdings.text: The challenge therefore to the constitutionality of s. 4(1) must fail.

anchor.surface_text: The challenge therefore to the constitutionality of s. 4 1 must fail. Then we turn to sub-s.  6 , which provides that any registration under sub-s.  1  may be suspended or cancelled by such authority,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registration under s.4(1) is eminently reasonable to enable the State to identify dealers and ensure tax collection, not a restriction on business.

holdings.text: Rule 14 which has been attacked has been made under the power conferred under s. 26 and it is not being disputed that if the main provisions contained in s. 4 are constitutional, the rule is within the ambit of the Act and the rule making power of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 which has been attacked has been made under the power conferred under s. 26 and it is not being disputed that if the main provisions contained in s. 4 are constitutional, the rule is within the ambit of the Act and the rule making power of the State Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 14 is framed under s.26's rule-making power and valid provided s.4 is constitutional.

holdings.text: The provision for cancellation of registration for failure to pay the tax or for fraudulently evading the payment of it is an additional coercive process which is expected to be immediately effective and enables the State to realise its revenues which are necessary for carrying on the administration in the interest of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the provision for cancellation of registration for failure to pay the tax or for fraudulently evading the payment of it is an additional coercive process which is expected to be immediately effective and enables the State to realise its revenues which are necessary for carrying on the administration in the interest of the general public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cancellation under s.4(6) is a reasonable coercive method for tax recovery in public interest, comparable to other processes.

holdings.text: Applying these tests we are of opinion that the cancellation of registration will be justified even though it results in the extinction of business as such cancellation is in respect of a tax meant for the general revenues of the State to carry on the administration in the interest of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests we are of opinion that the cancellation of registration will be justified even though it results in the extinction of business as such cancellation is in respect of a tax meant for the general revenues of the State to carry on the administration in the interest of the general public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prohibition via cancellation passes reasonableness test under Art.19(6) per Narendra Kumar, considering public revenue needs outweigh individual harm.

holdings.text: The fault for failure to pay the tax or fraudulent evasion in payment thereof lies in the circumstances entirely on the dealer and he cannot be heard to complain that cancellation of registration in such a case is a disproportionate restriction on the right to carry on business which cannot be justified in the interests of the general public.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional consideration: dealer effectively collects tax via price from consumer, so non-remittance is dealer's fault justifying cancellation.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 supports concept c14 by attributing fault to dealer for non-payment, justifying coercive cancellation
h5 supports Rule 14 by holding dealer bears full fault for non-payment/evasion and cannot complain of cancellation
The holding attributing fault to the dealer and denying complaint supports the proportionality test's conclusion to uphold cancellation.
Placing fault on the dealer supports the holding that cancellation as coercive process is justified.
h5 that dealer at fault cannot complain supports h4 justifying cancellation
The holding that fault lies entirely with the dealer who cannot complain about cancellation addresses the issue of reasonableness of the restriction.
